Award.AwardTitle: ICES:Large:Collaborative Research: The Role of Space, Time, and Information in Controlling Epidemics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The control of epidemics, broadly defined to range from human diseases such as influenza and smallpox to malware in communication networks, relies crucially on interventions such as vaccinations and anti-virals (in human diseases) or software patches (for malware). These interventions are almost always voluntary directives from public agencies; however, people do not always adhere to such recommendations, and make individual decisions based on their specific "self interest". Additionally, people alter their contacts dynamically, and these behavioral changes have a huge impact on the dynamics and the effectiveness of these interventions, so that "good" intervention strategies might, in fact, be ineffective, depending upon the individual response.

The goal of this project is to study the foundations of policy design for controlling epidemics, using a broad class of epidemic games on complex networks involving uncertainty in network information, temporal evolution and learning. Models will be proposed to capture the complexity of static and temporal interactions and patterns of information exchange, including the possibility of failed interventions and the potential for moral hazard. The project will also study specific policies posed by public agencies and network security providers for controlling the spread of epidemics and malware, and will develop resource constrained mechanisms to implement them in this framework.

This project will integrate approaches from Computer Science, Economics, Mathematics, and Epidemiology to give intellectual unity to the study and design of public health policies and has the potential for strong dissertation work in all these areas. Education and outreach is an important aspect of the project, and includes curriculum development at both the graduate and under-graduate levels. A multi-disciplinary workshop is also planned as part of the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The control of epidemics, be they human diseases or computer
viruses, leads to fundamentally new and challenging public
policy problems at the interface of economics and game
theory, computer science and mathematical epidemiology.  The
goal of this proposal was to study how to design policy for
controlling epidemics, using a broad class of epidemic games
on complex networks involving uncertainty in network
information, temporal evolution and learning.

In our research over the last 5 years, my students,
collaborators, and I, have developed new theories to help us
understand the effects of information and behavior in
predicting and managing infectious diseases.  Using math,
game theory economics, and computing, we've substantially
expanded our theoretical foundations for epidemic
management.


First, we studied the role of information in disease
prevention, showing how it becomes rational to tolerate
high levels of infectious disease risk when diagnostic
testing is slow or un-available.  This is inevitably
a situation where government action can interviene to
shift the community to a better public-health equilbrium.
We have also looked at how incidence-dependent costs
can effect the best responses to an on-going flu epidemic.

We have also studied the process of stigmatization,
showing how an societal evolutionary transition can occur:
while stigmatizing infected people can be good practice
in primitive societies without good medicine, good health
interventions like treatment can flip the situation so
that stigmatization actually makes things worse instead of
bettter.  Our theory provides a way of estimating the
turning point for this effect, and we have produced a
web site where people can experiment for themselves
with different conditions.

We have done extensive age-structured game modelling
applicable to diseases like HIV and Zika, to better
understand the costs and trade-offs inherint in their
control.
Most recently, I have developed a theory of minimal
sustainable burden that may help us understand the practical
limitations imposed on disease management by antibiotic and
more general drug resistance.


We have also developed and published an approach to risk
managment for emerging infectious diseases using the
standard fault-tree framework.  This model breaks the
emergence process down into four phases (exposure,
susceptibility, adaptation, and percolation) for each
transmission route, all of which can be targets of
risk-prevention measures.


This project has provided exciting research opportunities to
graduate students and postdoctoral researchers, who have
collaborated on the research and are co-authors on
manuscripts we have produced and are working to publish.
This research has been very interdisciplinary, with coming
from mathematics, biology, ecology, communications, computer
sciences, and even architecture departments.
